data.title: Program Definitions
data.thiscategory: partnershp with usda fs a guide for tribal governments obtain financial assistance guide
data.landingpagecontent:
• Challenge Cost-Share Agreement
    Forest Service cooperates with other parties to develop, plan and implement projects of mutual interest and benefit to all parties and enhance FS activities.
      • Parties may include: 
        • public and private agencies
        • Indian tribes
        • Organizations
        • Institutions
        • Individuals
      • It requires at least 20% cost match
      • Does not require competition (Interior and related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1992)
  • Collaborative Forest Landscape Restoration Program (CFLRP)
      • Purpose: encourage the collaborative, science-based ecosystem restoration of priority forest landscapes
      • Funds may be used to pay for up to 50% of cost of carrying out and monitoring ecological restoration treatments on NFS lands
        • No more than $4million may be spent CFLRP fund in any single fiscal year on any single project (Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009, USDA FS 2013a)
  • Collaborative Forest Restoration Program
      • Promote healthy watersheds
      • Reduce the threat of large, high-intensity wildfires
        • Insect infestation
        • Disease in forests
      • Eligible entities include:
        • Local Government
        • Tribal Government
        • Educational Institutions
        • Landowners
        • Conservation Organizations
        • Other public and private entities (Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act, 1978, Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance 2000) http://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/4e/workingtogether/grants/?cid=fsbdev3_022022
  • Community Forest and Open Space Conservation Program
      • Forest Service is authorized to provide financial assistance grants to establish community forests that provide defined benefits to:
        • Local Government
        • Tribal Government
        • Indian Tribes
        • Qualified nonprofit organizations (including land trusts)
      • Financial assistance cannot be used to:
        • Establish a community forest on tribal trust land
        • Only land owned in fee by Indian tribe is eligible
      • Community benefits include:
        • Economic benefits from sustainable forest management
        • Recreational benefits secured with public access
        • Natural resource protection
        • Forest based experiential learning; and
        • Replicable models of effective forest stewardship
      • Requirements:
        • 50% non-Federal match
        • Several requirements for land acquired through program
          • Public access
          • Managing land according to Community Forest Plan, developed with community involvement (2008 Farm Bill, Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance, 2011).
      • Community Wood Energy Program, Indian Tribes Eligible
        • FS Products to develop community wood energy plans and provides
          • Grants
          • Assistance
        • Competitive grants to:
          • Acquire
          • Upgrade
          • Demonstrate
        • (2008 Farm Bill, Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance, 2008a)
        • http://www.fpl.fs.fed.us/
      • Cooperative Fire Protection Agreement
  • Partner with parties to provide:
    • Wildland Fire Protection
    • Perform approved severity activities
    • Respond to presidentially declared emergencies or disasters under FEMA
  • Activities can occur on
    • Private land within or near NFS; or
    • Can be performed for benefit of those who occupy or use national forests or other lands administered by FS
  • FS can enter into reciprocal agreements with any fire organization maintaining fire protection facilities in vicinity of NFS lands
    • Reciprocal Fire Protection Act, 1955
    • Granger-Thye Act, 1950
    • Cooperative Funds and Deposits Act, 1975
    • Cooperative Funds Act, 1914
    • USDA FS 2009c
  • Cooperative Fire Protection:  State Fire Assistance Program
    • Supports State forestry agencies for wildfire suppression by:
      • Providing financial and technical support
      • For Equipment
      • Training
      • Creation of fire-adapted communities thru hazardous fuels reduction and planning
    • Projects target firefighter safety and fire planning
      • Firefighter training
      • Increased initial attach capability
      • Mobilization readiness
        For efficient suppression and prevention of wildfires on non-Federal forest lands and other non-Federal lands
  • All cooperators must provide:
    • 1:1 cost-share match
    • Indian tribes must apply through the local/State government (Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act, 1978, USDA FS, 2011).
  • Cooperative Law Enforcement Agreement
    • Used with FS partners with State or local governments to enforce State or local laws/ordinance on lands within or part of any unit of NFS
      • May be cross-jurisdictional  opportunities
      • Both Federal and State to enable tribal police officers to work on NFS lands
      • Indian tribes should contact their local law enforcement officer
  • Cooperative Research and Development Agreement
    • FS provides:
      • Personnel
      • Services
      • Facilities
      • Equipment
      • Other resources
        With or without reimbursement from cooperator to support scientific research
        Agreement between one or more Federal laboratories and one or more non-Federal parties
  • Economic Action Program
        • Provides technical assistance to rural communities on or near NFS lands
          • Dependent on the forest for heritage tourism and historic preservation
          • *Currently unfunded (USDA Office of Congressional and Intergovernmental Relations, 2007
          • National Forest-Dependent Rural Communities economic Diversification Act, 1990
  • Federal Financial Assistance for Research
        • Sec of Agriculture may conduct, support and cooperate in:
          • Investigations
          • Experiments
          • Tests
          • Other activities  deemed necessary to obtain, develop, demonstrate and disseminate scientific information about
            • Protecting
            • Managing
            • Using forest and rangeland resources in rural, suburban and urban areas
          • Secretary may cooperate with Indian tribes and is authorized to make competitive grants that will further research activities (Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act 1978).
  • Forest Health Protection
        • Protects non-Federal forest and tree resources from
          • Damaging forest insects
          • Disease causing agents
          • Invasive Plants
        • Develops and improves forest health protection technologies
        • Monitors health of Nation’s forests
        • Provides technical assistance
            • ON private, tribal trust land, Tribes can approach FS directly
            • FS can also conduct detection surveys and biological evaluations of forest insect and disease outbreaks on US DOI and tribal trust lands.
            • Indian tribes owning private land may apply for financial assistance through State forester
            • Indian tribes desiring financial assistance for trust lands, submit proposal to Forest Health Headquarters in Washington, D.C. through regional Forest Health Stat and Bureau of Indian Affairs forester.
          • Formula grants
          • Project grants
      • Forest Legacy Program
        • Provides grants to States to protect forest with the focus on working forests
          • Providing forest products and resource based jobs
          • Protecting air and water quality
          • Providing recreational opportunities
          • Protecting important fish and wildlife habitat
            • Those threatened or endangered species
        • Lands are protected through conservation easements
          • 65% of all projects
          • 35% fee simple purchases
        • Projects are protected selected by two step competitive process
          • Result in high-quality projects supported
            • Locally
            • Nationally
        • Forest Action Plans (Statewide Assessment and Resources Strategies)
          • States identify priority areas within State to target Forest Legacy Program funds
          • Indian tribes must apply through their State forester (USDA Forest Service 2013b).
      • Forest Stewardship Program
        • Project grants help private forest landowners
        • Individuals
          • Develop plans for managing non-Federal forest land
          • Projects cannot be conducted on tribal trust land
        • Only lands owned by Indian tribes is eligible
        • Forest Services offers primarily through State agencies to:
          • Help protect and improve soil
          • Water
          • Range
          • Aesthetics
          • Recreation
          • Timber
          • Fish and Wildlife resources
        • Requires parties to share 50% of costs
        • State forestry or equivalent; or
          • State agencies
          • Indian Tribes (must apply through the State forester or contact the FS national program lead
          • Non-profit organizations; and
          • Municipalities are eligible

data.title: Hazardous Fuels Treatment, Wildland Fire Hasardous Fuels Funds
data.thiscategory: partnershp with usda fs a guide for tribal governments obtain financial assistance guide
data.landingpagecontent:
• National Forest System Lands
    • FS may use contacts or enter into cooperative agreements for:
      • Hazardous fuels reduction
      • Training or
      • Monitoring associated with such hazardous fuel reduction activates on Federal lands.
      • Activities should focus on protecting lands identified in Community Wildfire Protection Plans (CSPPs) or equivalent (Consolidated Appropriations Act 2012)
  • Private or Trust Lands
    • FS may use up to $15 million to enter into cooperative agreements; or
    • Issue grants for hazardous fuels reduction; and
    • For training or monitoring associated with hazardous fuel reduction activities on non-Federal lands adjacent to Federal lands.
    • Funds can be used to protect communities
      • At risk near planned fuel reduction on NFS lands that place such communities at risk
    • Grants should be planned and implemented in high-priority areas identified in Community Wildfire Protection Plans
    • National Forest are to coordinate hazardous fuel reduction projects whenever possible and use all authorities available with:
      • State
      • Tribal
      • Local partners
  • International Forestry Programs
    • Works to address change in climate change
    • Conserve and protect critical global forest environments and resources
    • Improve lives of forest-dependent peoples
    • Accomplished through:
      • Direct and technical cooperation between FS and counterparts
        • Through grants and cooperative agreements with:
        • Non-profit organizations
        • Indian Tribes and other individuals, organizations and governments engaged in forest conservation and management.
        • Agreements address specific issues including:
          • Invasive species mitigation
          • Migratory Species Conservation
          • Legal trade in forest products
      • Program must contribute to goals and objectives of specific work plan between Office of International Programs and U.S. Agency for International Development or State Department.
      • Grants are limited to 5 years (International Forestry Cooperation Act, 1990, USDA Forest Service 2013e, Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance 1990c)
  • Joint Fire Science Program
    • Provide scientific support and tools to address wildland fuels issues (Interior and Related Agencies Appropriation Act, 1998).
    • Program run by 6 Government agencies, including:
      • Forest Service
      • U.S. Department of Interior agencies (BIA, BLM, NPS, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and U.S. Geological Survey)
      • Focuses on wildlands administered partner agencies and other federally administered lands
      • Programs’s agencies collaborate with:
        • Private
        • Non-profit Organizations
        • Tribal Governments
        • State Governments
        • Local Government
      • www.firescience.gov/
  • Memorandum of Agreement

Resolution of adverse effect(s) to historic properties through specific treatments must be documented in a National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA) Section 106 Memorandum of Agreement between the Forest service and the State Historic Preservation Officer, and, if appropriate, include the Advisory council on Historic Preservation Act (NHPA)

  • §106 Memorandum of Agreement between FS and State Historic Preservation Office; and
    • If appropriate include Advisory Council on Historic Prservation, Indian Tribes and other interested parties (USDA, FS 2008b).
  • Memorandum of Understanding
    • Enable Forest Service to formalize a relationship; or
      • Coordinate its activities with other parties for mutual benefit
      • Each party directs its own activities and uses its own resources
      • Cannot be used to obligate or fund projects
      • Each MOU must contain an expiration date of no more than 5 years from date of execution
      • MOUs are useful for government to government relationship (USDA FS 2009D).
  • Participating Agreement
    • Participating Agreement (PS), FS may enter into cooperatively performed projects of mutual interest and benefit with other parties (Cooperative Funds and Deposits Act 1975, USDA FS 2009e).
    • FS is authorized to advance funding to partner in prorated amount and initial project costs
    • Require minimum of 20% cost sharing by partner to demonstrate mutual interest and benefit in qualitative outcome for project
    • Cost sharing partnering organizations can include noncash and in-kind contributions toward overall project costs.
    • FS allowed to provide cash advances for the minimum amount needed to perform anticipated activities
      • No more than is needed for a 30 day period, whichever is less (USDA FS 2009e).
    • Pas are implemented with partnering organizations for local projects in targeted areas of FS land as provided by statute.
    • Partnerships that are national or multiregional in scope, a Master Participating Agreement (MPA) is signed
      • Individual Supplemental Project Agreements (SPAs) are executed on project by project basis to carry out the purpose of the MPS (USDA FS 20093)
  • Type 1 – Cooperative Environmental Education and Forest History Materials
    • Includes development and publication of:
      • Books
      • Pamphlets
      • Brochures
      • Audiovisual Materials
      • Not aps unless material specifically promotes environmental education or forest history (USDA Forest Service 2009e).
  • Type 2 – Cooperative Manpower, Job Training and Developmental Programs
    • Beneficial when cooperator has an existing specific job program and parties share cost
    • Requires at least a 20% cost match and does not require competition (USDA FS 2009e).
  • Type 3: Cooperative Pollution Abatement Agreement – Enables cooperatively performed projects involving construction, operation and maintenance of facilities relating to pollution abatement.
    • Eligible parties include:
      • Indian tries
      • Public and Private Agencies
      • Organizations
      • Institutions; or
      • Persons
    • Requires  Competition
  • Type 4:  Forestry Protection Agreement – enables cooperatively performed projects involving:
    • Fire prevention
    • Fuel management
    • Insect and disease control
    •  Noxious weed control
    • Tree planting and seeding
    • Erosion control
    • Abandoned mine reclamation
    •  Land restoration
    •  Hazardous material identification
    • Water testing and protection, and air pollution abatement.
  • “Passport in Time” (PIT) Program
    • Engages volunteers in stewardship projects that benefit cultural resources and comply with
      • Natural Historic Preservation Act (NHPA)
      • Archaeological Resources Protection Act
      • Other Federal historic preservation legislation
    • Volunteer involvement through PIT exposes the public to broad range of natural and cultural resource issues
      •  Fosters public awareness
      • Support of Federal land management (USDA FS 2008c).
  • Programmatic Agreement – May be negotiated and executed at
    • National
    • Regional
    • State
    • Forest Levels
    • Agreements enable the FS and the Indian tribe to set up a process for
      • Consultation
      • Coordination
      • Cooperation
    • Between the national forest and
      • State Historic Preservation Officers
      • Tribal Historic Preservation Officers
      • Advisory Council on Historic Preservation
      • Indian Tribes
      • Consulting Parties
    • The agreements also lays out the conditions under which national forest based planning can take place under uniform standards for
      • Inventorying
      • Evaluating
      • Protecting
      • Enhancing
      • Consulting; and
      • Managing historic properties
    • Affected by the activities and programs administered and carried out by the individual national forest (USDA FS 2008b; Protection of Historic Properties 2004).
  • Protocols – Apart from the Programmatic Agreement, the FS and the Indian Tribe can create additional protocols such as:
    • Consultation for how/when consultation should occur; and
    • Protocol for potential inadvertent discovery and identification of: 
      • Native American human remains
      • Funerary objects
      • Sacred objects
      • Objects of cultural patrimony found on public lands administered by the national forest (USDA FS 2008b).
  • Repatriation
    • Native American Graves and Protection and Repatriation Act of 1990, provides a process for museums and Federal agencies to return certain Native American artifacts/cultural items
      • Human remains
      • Funerary objects
      • Sacred objects
      • Objects of cultural patrimony

To lineal descendants and culturally affiliated Indian Tribes and Alaska Native Villagers.

  • Areas that contain significant human remains or cultural objects,

Tribe should assist FS with preparation with creation of Plan for Treatment and Disposition of Human Remains and Other Cultural Items from NF pursuant to the law. (FSH 509.13.

    • Specific Example for Repatriation Agreement to be executed (FSH 1509.13)
  • Reburials – Consultation with affected Tribe or lineal descendant, the Secretary of Agriculture may authorize use of NFS land by the Indian tribe or lineal descendant for the reburial of human remains or cultural items in possession of Indian tribe or lineal descendant that have been unearthed from the NFS land or an adjacent site
    • The Tribe’s designated representative may contact the FS where the remains were found to formally request a reburial.
    • FS will then consult with the Tribe regarding the proposed place, manner, and timing of the reburial
    • Parties will also discuss projected physical costs of reburial as well as, tribal costs including travel to the site
    • FS will then submit a request for funds to FS Tribal Relations office.
    • If Office approves, budget for reburial will initiate and funds will go to region at time.
    • Subsequent to approval of funds, FS and Indian tribe may negotiate a Memorandum of Understanding detailing reburial sites, including place, manner and time (FSH 1509.15) (25 USC 32A, Section 3053, USDA FS 2012b).
  • Research Cost-Reimbursable Agreement – Allow the FS to get certain goods or services from State cooperative institutions and colleges and universities to conduct:
    • Agricultural research
    • Extension or teaching activities for mutual interest
    • Parties may not benefit in same qualitative way
    • FS may enter these agreements with State cooperative instituions;
      • Other colleges and universities
    • FS may cooperate only with universities and colleges that offer baccalaureate or high degree (4 year) for teaching activities
    • Agreement does not require matching funds from cooperator
      • Advance payments are prohibited (National Agricultural Research, Extension and Teaching Policy Act, 1977 (USDA FS 2009e; USDA FS 2009f)
  • Research Joint Venture Agreement – Enables FS to do research projects with any entity or individual to serve mutual interest and benefit of parties in:
    • Agricultural research
    • Extension and teaching activities
    • FS and other parties share costs
      • Agreement requires a 20% cost match
      • Reimbursable and advance payments are possible depending on type of cooperator
      • Agreements are unsolicited
      • (National Agricultural Research, Extension and Teach Policy At, 1977; USDA FS 2009e & 2009f).
  • Rural Development, Forestry and Communities – Enable FS to assist rural areas analyze and assess:
    • Forest resource opportunities
    • Maximize local economic potential through market development and expansion
    • Diversify communities economic base
    • Funding may be allocated for things as:
      • Technical Assistance
      • Training and Education
      • Equipment
      • Marketing
      • All costs associated with making services available to rural communities
      • Indian tribes are directly eligible
      • Executive Order requires annual Dept of the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations direction to implement (Amended for 2018 Farm Bill – waiting for new guidance)
  • Secure Rural Schools and Community Self-Determination Act

Allows FS to enter into contracts, grants, cooperative agreements and partnership agreements with for eligible projects that have been recommended by the Resource Advisory Committee (RAC) and approved by the FS.

      • Local governmental entities
      • Tribal Nations
      • Individuals
      • Non-profit and for-profit organizations
  • Act encourages project proposals from a wide range of proponents including:
    • Indian tribes
    • Tribes may also participate as RAC members
  • Planning and implementing projects should help improve cooperative relationships among people that use and care for Federal land and the agencies that manage the Federal land (Secure Rural Schools and Community Self-Determination Act, 2000; USDA FS 2009e and 2013f).
  • Title II funds may be used for:
    • Protection
    • Restoration
    • Enhancement of fish and wildlife habitat
    • Other resource objectives consistent with Secure Rural Schools Act on Federal land and on non-Federal land where projects would benefit resources on Federal land (USDA FS 2013f)
  • Purposes of Secure Rural Schools Act
    • Making additional investments in and creating employment opportunities through Title II-funded projects that:
      • Improve the maintenance of existing infrastructure
      • Implement stewardship objectives that enhance forest ecosystems; and
      • Restore and improve land health and water quality (USDA FS 2013f)
  • Funds may be used for projects with broad based support and have objectives that may include:
    • Road, trail and infrastructure maintenance or obliteration;
    • Soil productivity improvement;
    • Improvements in forest ecosystem health;
    • Watershed restoration and maintenance;
    • Restoration, maintenance and improvement of wildlife and fish habitat;
    • Control of noxious and exotic weeds; and
    • Re-Establishment of native species (Secure Rural School and Community Self-Determination Act 2000, USDA FS 2013f).
  • The act itself does not require matching funds or service from parties to an agreement
  • Act was designed to provide short-term assistance to rural communities; and
  • Subject to annual reauthorization or termination by Congress
  • Stewardship Agreements and Contracts
    • FS and BLM have authority to enter into stewardship end results contracting projects for up to 10 years
    • Stewardship projects help achieve land management goals while meeting local and rural community needs, including:
      • Contributing to sustainability of rural communities
      • Providing a continuing source of local income and employment
      • Stewardship projects focus on “end result” ecosystem benefits and outcomes rather than on what is removed from the land
      • FS staffs collaborate to build community partnerships with cooperating Federal, State and local governmental agencies, Tribal governments, non-governmental organizations and any interested group or individuals to develop projects (USDA FS 2008a, 2014 Farm Bill)
    • Other features include:
      • Apply value of timber or other forest products removed as an offset against cost of services received
      • Apply excess receipts from a project to authorized stewardship project
      • Select contracts and agreements on a “best value” basis
      • Award a contract or agreement up to 10 years
    • Stewardship contracts and agreements may be used for treatments to improve, maintain or restore forest or range land health;
      • Restore or Maintain water quality
      • Improve fish and wildlife habitat; and
      • Reduce  hazardous fuels that pose risks to communities and ecosystems values (USDA FS 2008a, 2014 Farm Bill)
    • FS enters into a contract where:
      • The FS designs the stewardship project
      • Is the beneficiary of the work
      • Pays the costs of the project; and
      • Contractors compete for the project
    • Stewardship agreements are stewardship projects where there is joint endeavor with:
      • Mutual benefits and mutual interest
      • Partner is:
        • State government
        • Local government
        • Indian tribe
        • Non-profit
      • Features include:
        • Enabling FS and BLM to apply value of timber or other forest products removed as offset:
        • Cost of services received
        • Apply excess receipts from project to other authorized stewardship projects
        • Select contracts and agreements on a “best value” basis
        • Award contract or agreements up to 10 years
    • Stewardship contracts and agreements may be used for treatments to:
      • Improve
      • Maintain
      • Restore forest or range land health
      • Restore or maintain water quality
      • Improve fish and wildlife habitat
      • Reduce hazardous fuels that pose risks to communities or ecosystem values (USDA FS 2008a, 2014 Farm Bill)
    • Forest Service would enter contract where FS designs stewardship project
      • Is beneficiary of work
      • Pays costs of project
      • Contractors compete for project
    • Stewardship agreements applicable for projects where there is joint endeavor with mutual benefits:
      • State government
      • Local government
      • Indian tribe
      • Nonprofit
      • Some features include requiring cost share of 20% or more not permitting a profit incentive and allowing for termination by either party
      • Contractors are typically not competing for projects (USDA FS 2008a, 2014 Farm Bill)
  • Technology Transfer Agreement – FS may enter into cooperative research and development agreements (CRADAs) for technological transfer for commercial purposes
    • FS may provide:
      • Personnel
      • Services
      • Facilities
      • Equipment
      • Other resources with or without reimbursement from cooperator to support scientific research aimed at developing commercially viable products or services.
    • Agreement should be between one or more Federal laboratories and one or more non-Federal parties
    • FS may enter into CRDAs with Indian tribes or tribal entities that fit description of industrial organization with tribal colleges that are non-profits (Federal Technology Transfer Act, 1986).
  • Tribal Forest Protection Act – carry out projects on NFS lands to protect Indian forest land, range land or tribal communities
    • Submit requests to Secretary of Agriculture and Secretary of Interior to enter into cooperative agreements or contracts (TFPA 2004)
    • Forest Service officials may provide advice and information to Indian tribes in advance of Tribe submitting proposals for stewardship contracts
      • Other instruments
      • Contracts
      • Agreements
    • FS may assist Indian tribes in developing proposals that are consistent with TFPA
    • Line officers may only accept proposals from a representative of governing body of Indian tribe, (i.e. Tribal Chair, or Tribal Council)
    • Tribe may submit a proposal on behalf of tribal member that owns an allotment meeting qualification for a project
    • Note: Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation land are not held in trust with restriction against alienation
      • Such lands are outside the scope of the TFPA
    • An Indian tribe to which an individual Indian allottee belongs, may submit request to FS to enter into an agreement or contract to carry out project to protect allotee’s land.
    • The Secretary may issue public notice of initiation of any necessary environment review of potential of entering into agreement of contract with the Tribe no later than 120 days after request is submitted (TFPA 2004, USDA FS 2008a).
  • Urban and Community Forest Program – (National and State led program)
    • National program grant assists
      • State foresters
      • Equivalent State agencies
      • Indian tribes
      • State-recognized tribes
      • Interested members of the public
      • Private nonprofit organizations in urban and community forestry programs in cities and communities.
    • Requires parties to share 50% of costs and program must have national application
    • Organizers of projects
      • Plan
      • Establish
      • Manage
      • Protect trees, forests green spaces, and related natural resources in and adjacent to cities and towns.
    • Individual land owners are not eligible
    • Groups owning land are
    • States have manage their own program with varying criteria (Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act, 1978, Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance, 1978).
  • Volunteer Agreement – Volunteers may be reimbursed for incidental expenses incurred that are required and directly related to their service.
  • Volunteer Fire Assistance Program – provides financial, technical and other assistance through State forestry agencies to:
    • Organize
    • Equipment
    • Train small, local fire departments in rural communities with populations under 10,000 for prevention and suppression of fires
    • State foresters pass funding through to local fire departments and fire training academies
    • Grants are $5,000 or less
    • All cooperators must provide 1:1 cost share match
    • Indian tribes must apply through their State government (cooperative Forestry Assistance Act, 1978; USDA FS 2011).
    • Watershed Restoration and Enhancement Agreement Authority (Wyden Amendment - FS enters into Cooperative Agreements and Participating Agreements with:
      • Federal
      • Tribal
      • State
      • Local governments
      • Private and Non-profit entities
      • Landowners to improve:
        • Fish
        • Wildlife
        • Other resources on NFS lands within a watershed and reduce risk of natural disaster where public safety may be threatened.
      • Purpose:
        • Protection
        • Restoration
        • Enhancement of fish and wildlife and other resources
        • Reduction of risk for natural disaster
        • Indian tribes and State designated tribes are eligible
      • Requires only  mutual benefit, not necessarily mutual interest
      • No minimum match requirement (Wyden Amendment, 1998, catalog of Federal domestic Assistance, 1998).
  • Wood education and Resource Center (WERC)
    • Competitive Grants Program
    • Authority provides funds on a cost share basis for project enhancement for sustained forest products production for primary and secondary hardwood industries located on eastern hardwood forest region.
    • Non-Federal agencies
      • Public and private agencies
      • State
      • Local
      • Tribal governments
      • Institutions of higher education
      • Non-profit organizations
      • For profit organizations
      • Corporations
      • Business are eligible
    • As of 2014, unfunded. This could change in 2018 Farm Bill
  • Hazardous Fuels Wood to Energy (W2E) Grant Program
    • Funds projects where some or all of woody biomass is generated from NFS lands as result of
      • Hazardous fuel treatments
      • Forest restoration activities
      • Insect and disease mitigation
      • Catastrophic weather events
      • Thinning overstocked stands
    • Projects that use woody biomass from multiple land ownerships
      • State
      • Tribal
      • Private lands
      • Multiple sources – considered as long as some of woody biomass is from NFS lands
        • Wood Products facilities
        • Urban wood waste
      • Projects that do not anticipate using any wood from NFS lands will not be eligible (1990 Farm Assistance 2012; Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2014)
  • Woody Biomass Utilization Assistance Program – Provides annual project grants or cooperative agreements to further long-term forest health through enterprises that support:
    • Forest management
    • Hazardous fuel reduction
    • Other restoration activities
    • Program focuses on commercially viable wood energy project development through several different mechanisms:
      • Statewide wood energy teams to support expansion of wood energy installations through cooperative agreements
      • Funding for the development of clusters of projects either geographically clustered or sector clusters, through grants to help with the design
        • Colleges
        • Hospitals, etc
      • Grants to assist with the design and other preconstruction costs of installing a wood energy system
    • Eligible entities include:
    • Nonprofit organizations
    •  Local
    • State
    • Tribal governments
    • Business
    • Companies
    • Corporation (for profit)
    • Special purpose districts (public utilities, fire, conservation, port)

(National Forest Dependent Rural Communities Economic Diversification Act of 1990, USDA FS 2013g.

data.title: Definitions
data.landingpagecontent:
• Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA), is a federal law passed in 1990.  Provides a process for museums and federal agencies to resolve possessory rights to certain Native American cultural items – human remains, funerary objects, sacred objects, or objects of cultural patrimony – to lineal descendants and cultural affiliated Indian Tribes and Native Hawaiian organizations.
    • NAGPRA does not, explicitly address reburial of Native American human remains repatriated by museums and federal agencies subject to NAGPRA.
    • NAGPRA provides for Indian tribes to take possession of the remains, but does not establish the authority to rebury on NFS lands
  •  National Historic Preservation ACT (NHPA)  was passed in 1966 and substantially amended in 1980 and 1992.  THE NHPA, requires all federal agencies to consider the effects of their projects and programs on historic properties and provides the structure and direction for all federal management of important cultural resources.
  • Archaeological Resources Protection Act (APRA) – passed in 1979 in recognition of  archaeological resources as in irreplaceable part of America’s heritage and that they were endangered increasingly  because of the escalating commercial value of a small portion of the contents of archaeological
  • Archaeological Resources Protection Act (ARPA) – passed in 1979, recognition of archaeological resources as an irreplaceable part of America’s heritage and that they were endangered increasingly because of escalating commercial value of a small portion of contents of archeological sites.
    • ARPA prohibits unauthorized excavation on federal and Indian lands, which adds a layer of protection to the repatriated and reburied items
    • ARPA establishes standards for permissible excavation, prescribes civil and criminal penalties, requires agencies to identify archeological sites and encourages cooperation between Federal agencies and private individuals.
  • Federal regulations (36 CFR §800 and 54 USC §300101 requires agencies to consult with various parties, (i.e. State and Tribal Historic Preservation Officers{SHPO/THPOs}, Indian tribes, or Native Hawaiian organizations and others – to determine if the proposed project may have an effect on a property listed on or eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places, and if so, what measures might be appropriate to minimize or mitigate that effect.
    • Many reburials will have very little or no effect to historic properties when reburials avoid the salient features of known historic properties, do not require physical site preparation and avoid extensive ground disturbance.
    • Such cases usually conclude with an official NHPA determination of “no effect” or “no historic properties affected” or “no adverse effect” (36 CFR 800.4(d) and 800.5)
  • Applying NAGPRA, NHPA and CHCA
    • Tribal governments and the Forest Service should have meaningful, government – to – government, discussion to determine.
      • Mutually acceptable solutions to protect and manage reburial sites
      • How Tribal government organizations will be involved in protecting and managing their reburial sties
      • What framework will be used for future collaborative efforts, with special emphasis on how to incorporate tribally-authorized members to help protect reburial sites
    • Native American and Alaska native concerns expressed most often during consultation or through personal testimony include:
      • Reburied remains may be disturbed in the future
      • Forest Service staff may interfere with tribal spiritual practices
      • Reburial of culturally unidentifiable human remains should be conducted with sensitivity and in a traditionally appropriate manner

data.title: Tribal Cultural and Heritage Cooperation Authority Technical Guide
data.landingpagecontent: View the Tribal Cultural and Heritage Cooperation Authority Technical Guide (2.5mb PDF)

data.title: Line Officers Resonsibilities for Re-burial
data.landingpagecontent:
Responsibility for authorizing reburials on NFS lands, resides with the Regional Foresters.  Regional Foresters may delegate that authority in writing, to Forest and Grassland Supervisors under their supervision.

  • Timeframe:  ensure that requests for reburial are addressed in a timely manner.
  • Consultation:  When authorizing reburials, consult with the lineal descendants or culturally affiliated process. This my include site protection and management protocols.
    • An understanding may take the form of correspondence rather than a formal MOU.
    • This agreement may include reburial of human remains and associated funerary objects (FSH §1509.13)
  • Notification:  Inform the appropriate law enforcement agents of reburial activities in order to protect reburial sites through monitoring and surveillance activities.
  • Avoid Conflicting Uses:  Identify areas where anticipated uses will not cause future impacts or physical harm to the site and in consultation, a location that is consistent with tribal cultural, spiritual and religious requirements for reburial purposes.
  • Mitigation Measures:  Develop and implement mitigation measures in consultation with tribal governments, clans and indiviuals to minimize or avoid adverse impacts to reburial sites that may be caused by particular land uses. Ensure the measures will be implemented for the long run
  • Coordination and Reporting:  A critical first step is to ensure that all requests for reburial are reported and coordinated with the Regional Tribal rlatins program Manager, Regional Heritage Resources Program Manager, and appropriate law enforcement personnel.

data.title: Management Tools - Reburial
data.landingpagecontent:
• Placement of remains in a historic property, under the provisions of NHPA and ARPA. Both laws provide for additional security of the site and associated information.
  • When remains are known to have been removed from a specific site, evaluate, on a case-by-case basis. Alternative locations should be considered if a reburial would cause adverse effect to known properties.
  • When remains are not reburied at the site of their original interment, consider alternative location at another historic property; evaluate reburial plans on a case-by-case bases.
  • During consultation, provide information to Indian tribes, clans, and family members regarding appropriate reburial locations, including the location where the remains were removed. 
    • It is important to determine the status of the reburial location in regard to the Sacred Sites Executive Order 13007, the Forest Service must depend on Indian tribes to identify and designate sacred sites.
  • Redirect public use away from reburial sites, including those not located on a historical property. This may require landscape level consideration of potential land and resource management actions.
  • Restrict Permit Issuance – Deny or redirect permit for use of areas or materials that contain reburial sites.
  • During NF and Grassland planning process, ensure that consideration is given to special areas identified by Indian tribes.
    • Create planning information and directin that enable and protects areas suitable for reburial, as well as previous reburial sites.

data.title: Confidentiality
data.landingpagecontent:
• FS personnel should ensure that information about reburial locations is kept confidential by consulting person –to-person. This will ensure that the appropriate FS staff and Indian tribe, or descendent community retains documentation.
    • Restriction of access to information will help keep reburial locations protected from future development or disturbance.
    • Agency must provide for the long-term security of the confidential information and ensure that the locational information is available during planning efforts.

data.title: A Sacred Site - What is it?
data.landingpagecontent:
“. . . any specific, discrete, narrowly delineated location on Federal land that is identified by an Indian Tribe, or Indian individual determined to be an appropriately authoritative representative of an Indian religion, as sacred by virtue of its established religious significance to, or ceremonial use by, an Indian religion; provided that the tribe or appropriately authoritative representative of an Indian religion has informed the agency of the existence of such a site.”

Agencies are required to, where appropriate, maintain the confidentiality of sacred sites.  Executive Order 13007 establishes that Indian Tribes and appropriate representatives of AI/AN religions (not the agencies) identify which locations are sacred sites under the Executive Order).

Basic:  Under Sacred Sites EO, does not require that a Sacred Site have material cultural components; it could be a natural spring, or rock shelter, a landscape, or even a body of water, as examples.

data.title: USDA FS Sacred Sites Policy
data.landingpagecontent:
• Accommodate access to access to and ceremonial use of Indian sacred sites by Indian religious practitioners
  • Avoid adversely affecting they physical integrity of such sacred sites
  • Maintain the confidentiality of sacred sites where appropriate
  • Implement procedures to execute these provisions
  • Ensure reasonable notice is provided of proposed actions that may restrict future access to or ceremonial use of, or will adversely affect the physical integrity of sacred sites.

data.title: Sacred Sites as Spiritual Connections to the Landscape
data.landingpagecontent:
• Spiritual connection between tribal people and their ancestors (including all aspects of the natural world) is expressed through the existence and use of cultural resources or traditional ceremonial sites left in place and in context.
  • Can be:
    • Burial Places
    • Sacred areas
    • Historic Trails
    • Travel Corridors
    • Subsistence locations
  • A sacred site is not necessarily a place, but may be a geographic feature connected to a creation story.
  • A sacred site is not necessarily a place where anyone goes
    • Example:  ANWR (Arctic national Wildlife Refuge) contains

Caribou birthing grounds
Those grounds are sacred to most Athabascan people and they do not go there

  • Knowledge of sites is often private and cannot be shared with non-tribal members, or the public
  • It is important to understand the nature of private knowledge among indigenous communities
  • Some things cannon be share with outsiders without violating cultural customs and beliefs

data.title: Sacred Sites and the National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA)
data.landingpagecontent:
• Federal law passed in 1966 that governs historic preservation policy of the federal government
  • BASICS:  A Sacred Site might not be protected under the NHPA, if it does not have a material, cultural component, such an archeological site, or structure.
  • Created the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation (ACHP), an independent agency of the United States government that oversees federal preservation efforts.
  • NHPA and its regulations are the most important tools for protecting historic sites affected by projects undertaken, funded or regulated by the federal government
  • Section 106 of the NHPA requires agencies to consider the impact of undertakings they carry out, fund or regulate on historic properties and to give the ACHP the opportunity to comment on those undertakings. 
  • Regulations established pursuant to §106, 36 CFR 800, are that federal agencies
    • Make attempts to identify historic properties that might be impacted by their actions
    • The attempts include seeking input from knowledgeable sources
    • Make attempts to avoid, minimize or mitigate any impacts their actions may have on historic properties that might be impacted by their actions
      • These attempts including seeking input from knowledgeable sources, including Tribes
    • Make attempts to avoid, minimize or mitigate any impacts their actions may have on historic properties
    • Consult with interested parties on how to avoid, minimize, or mitigate impacts to historic properties
    • Consult with the appropriate federally recognized Indian Tribes when Native American historic properties are involved

These requirements are highly significant when it comes to preserving Native American historical sites.  The requirement to identify historic properties makes it less probable that these resources will be unintentionally destroyed.

Section 106 of NHPA – ensures that historic preservation is considered in federal project planning. Work with State Historic Preservation Officers and Tribal Historic Preservation Officers as well as, Federal Preservation Officers should all collaborate during the process. The Section 106 review process is used to determine a federal project’s effect on historic properties.

Link to 36 CFR 800, from Advisory Council on Historic Preservation

data.title: About the FS Tribal Relations Strategic Plan
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:

    • Excel as High Performing Agency

data.title: Summary of Goals and Objectives
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:
The strategic plan is organized by the following:

  1. Goals - high-level goals are derived from the Forest Service mission and fiduciary responsibility to Tribes.
    • What are the key values we are trying to address?
    • What is the problem you are faced with?
    • Why are we addressing this topic?
    • What does success look like?
  2. Objectives - actionable statements that focus on what must be accomplished to achieve the goals
    • What are the most important actions and the order in which they are accomplished?
    • Who is the target of the actions?
    • Who is affected by the action?
    • Who is accountable?
    • Where the overlap is (is there opportunity to double up on priority actions?
    • Where are the roadblocks?
  3. Outcomes - provide the quantitative or qualitative measureable effect the program will accomplish
    • What are the real and lasting changes we want to produce?
    • What needs to be catalyzed or changed?
    • What do FS employees most need?
    • What are we missing?
  4. Focused Actions – are targeted actions to achieve the outcomes
    • Will directions and policy need to change?
    • Is the product within the purview of the Agency? The Department?
    • How do products accomplish the objectives or outcomes?

data.title: Vision for Tribal Relations in Forest Service
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:
• FS recognizes and supports the sovereignty of American Indians and Alaska Native tribal nations and self-determination of tribal peoples through:
    • Building
    • Maintaining
    • Enhancing government to government relationships with Tribal Governments
  • FS engages inclusively with:
    • People in mutual respect
    • Active collaboration
    • Share stewardship
  • FS promotes
    • Meaningful nation-to-nation consultation with tribal nations; and
    • Communities in ways that foster free, prior and informed consent
  • FS Implementation of agency programs and activities in a manner that:
    • Honors Indian Tribes’ treaty rights
    • Fulfills the agency’s trust responsibilities; and
    • Respects each independent tribal nation and their cultures.
  • Summary of Goals and Objectives
    • Sustain Sovereignty Through Shared Stewardship
      • Objective:  1A – Build, strengthen, and uphold nationa to nation relationships that sustain tribal sovereignty and help meet the Agency’s trust responsibility and treaty obligations
      • 1B – Engage in shared stewardship of our Nation’s lands, including tribal and FS lands and resources, to support healthy and resilient forests and grasslands that benefit tribal communities and help the FS better accomplish its mission.
    • Deliver Benefits to Tribal Communities and the Public
      • Objective 2.A – Facilitate delivery of benefits to tribal communities and the public
      • 2.B – Strengthen availability, access, use and resilence of tribally important resources and places
      • 2.C – Leverage partners capabilities.
    • Apply Knowledge Inclusively
      • 3.A – Facilitate the appropriate and ethical gathering and exchange of knowledge and perspectives that lead to beneficial actions on forests and grasslands across boundaries.
      • 3. B – Promote diversity and inclusion within the agency in support of the Forest service Strategic Plan Management Objective “Recruit a Diverse Workforce”
    • Excel in Tribal Relations Leadership
      • Showcase outstanding examples of collaboration with Tribes, promoting positive agency engagement to enhance tribal relations
      • Continuously improve how the Forest Service creates, maintains, and improves tribal relations.
      • Enhance the Forest Service ability to maintain an accountable process for its consultation and other interactions with Tribes.

data.title: Mission of the Forest Service
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:
• Consistent with the FS mission, the Forest Service expresses a culture that:
    • Uses sound advice an appropriate assistance to enhance and maintain important relationships with Tribes and indigenous communities
    • Recognizes and supports the inherent sovereign status and reserved rights of Tribes
    • Honors the Federal trust responsibility to Tribes
    • Excels at conducting substantive and meaningful consultative processes with Tribes
    • Supports Tribal Governments’ and indigenous communities’ rights to pursue and enhance the vitality of their cultures, economies and lands.
    • Promotes collaborative natural and cultural resource management, including protecting and providing access to tribal sacred places.
    • Encourages use of traditional knowledge in combination with the best Western science and technology.
    • Advances American Indians and Alaska Natives in the workforce.
    • Respects and helps maintain tribal connections to traditional landscapes.
    • Facilitates information exchange between Tribes and Forest Service researchers.

data.title: Sustain our Nation's Forests and Grasslands
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:
By recognizing and supporting the sovereignty of tribal nations and expertise of tribal peoples, the FS can enhance shared stewardship to better sustain the Nation’s forests and grasslands.

  • Provides channel for Tribes to be involved in FS programs and activities
  • Create benefits within the agency’s mission responsive to local and affiliated community needs and interests.

Objectives/Outcomes

  • Objective 1.A – Build, strengthen and uphold nation to nation relationships that sustain tribal sovereignty and help meet the agency’s trust responsibility and treat obligations.
    • Outcomes – Tribal nations and the FS engage in relationships that reinforce mutual interests and shared decision making.
  • Objective 1.B – Engage in shared stewardship of our Nation’s lands, including tribal and FS lands and resources, to support healthy and resilient forests and grasslands that benefit tribal communities and help the Forest Service better accomplish its mission.
    • Tribal Governments and tribal communities sustainably receive cultural, social, economic, and ecological benefits from actions taken in partnership with the Forest Service.  The FS receives tribal expertise, capacity and resources through partnerships that help the agency sustain the Nation’s forests and grasslands, and fulfill the agency’s objective to strengthen communities.

Focused Actions

  • Apply the FS mission in ways that fulfill the agency’s trust responsibilities and treaty obligations.
  • Help protect tribal reserved rights as they pertain to FS lands and resources, as applied through policies, programs and projects
  • Consult early and often to ensure all topics are on the table and relationships are maintained
  • Convene regularly scheduled interactions between tribal and FS unit leadership to maintain productive relationships and collaborative opportunities
  • Develop and enhance bilateral agreements
  • Foster projects and partnerships that result in completion of mutually desired outcomes
  • Expand use of FS general authorities and tribally specific authorities such as TPA, CHCA
  • Develop and implement FS activities that highlight, engage and promote traditional ecological knowledge, preserve traditional cultures, and contribute to community well-being
Develop and distribute case studies of success resulting from agency and tribal partnerships, with consent of Tribes.

data.title: Deliver Benefits to the Public
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:
FS provides goods and services locally, nationally, and internationally.

  • Trust responsibility and treaty obligations, FS have particular focus on benefits we provide to Tribal communities.
  • Enhance focus by connecting agency’s mission to traditional tribal lifeways and values
  • Various programs serve to improve intra-agency coordination, increase program delivery efficiency, maximize scarce program resources, and solve problems through cooperation with partners

Objectives/Outcomes

  • Objective 2.A – Facilitate delivery of benefits to tribal communities and the public
    • Outcome – Tribal nations and their constituent communities receive the benefits of the FS land management actions, expertise, and knowledge.
    • These benefits span jurisdictions to accomplish desired protections, conservation and uses
  • Objective 2.B – Strengthen availability, access, use and resilience of tribally important resources and places.
    • Outcome – Tribal citizens have appropriate access to important resources and sacred places on National Forest System lands. Projects and partnerships promote connections between the agency’s mission and traditional native lifeways.
  • Objective 2.C – Leverage partners’ capabilities
    • Outcome – Improve intra-agency and inter-agency coordination, and expand partnerships with third parties, to create efficiencies in program delivery in support of the FS mission to promote and develop markets for forest products.

Focused Actions

  • Review and revise policies to better reflect tribal engagement and participation in FS decision making, programs and projects
  • Seek opportunities to partner with Tribes in work across boundaries and leverage resources to accomplish together what we could not each do on our own.
  • Work with Tribes to identify barriers to effective partnerships and consultation
  • Develop and distribute useful information about FS actions and opportunities
  • Identify and work with partners who can help create benefits for the FS
  • When the FS is unable to meet a Tribe’s requests, be clear and transparent in explaining to the Tribe why this is not possible
  • Use appropriate conflict resolution processes when disagreements between a Tribe and the FS occur.
  • Continue implementation of the 2012 Sacred Site Report recommendations
  • Expand use of FS general authorities, and tribally specific authorities such as TPA, and CHCA, in support of connecting Tribes to traditional places and resources
  • Implement FS programs, including Federal financial assistance and technical assistance programs that apply to Tribal Governments and tribal communities
  • Explore new ways, including research and management, to provide appropriate tribal access and use of FS resources.
  • Expand partnership agreements
  • Develop and nurture new partnerships
  • Develop strong personal and organization relationships with tribally supporting organizations

data.title: Apply Knowledge Globally
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:
The Forest Service is a provider and consumer of knowledge about management, leadership, and resources from many diverse sources.

  • Western Science
  • Citizen Science
  • Native Science
  • Traditional Knowledge - Incorporating Tribal knowledge can improve the agency’s resources management decisions and outcomes
  • Forest Service must balance legal obligation to support tribal nations, while at same time delivering our mission

Objectives/Outcomes

  • Objective 3.A – The appropriate and ethical gathering and exchange of knowledge and perspectives from tribal citizens that lead to beneficial actions
    • Outcome – Tribal knowledge and wisdom are respected, protected, encouraged, and appropriately used in Forest Service activities. 
    • Tribal communities, FS personnel, and our partners engage in productive and positive relationships that lead to mutual understanding, respect and participation in activities that are mutually beneficial.
  • Objective 3.B – Promote diversity, and inclusion within the agency, in support of the FS Strategic Plan Management Objective “Recruit a diverse workforce.”
    • Outcome – Creativity and effectiveness in Forest Service decision making are enhanced through including and sharing of diverse experiences, knowledge, and perspectives of indigenous peoples.

Focused Actions

  • Facilitate transfer of knowledge between the FS and Tribes, sharing Western science and traditional ecological knowledge to leverage the benefits of both
  • Engage Tribes early in forest plan revisions and research plans
  • Engage Tribes early in initial planning of programs and projects
  • Engage Tribes in Forest Service research and technical assistance activities that meet tribal interests and requests
  • Coordinate with Human Resources and Civil Rights staffs to outreach and recruit American Indian and Alaska Natives
  • Facilitate and support Forest Service employees direct interactions with Tribal Government staffs and tribal culture bearers
  • Create and distribute appropriate training materials and relevant publications that increase FS personnel knowledge, understanding and competencies in tribal relations

data.title: Excel as a High Performing Agency
data.thiscategory: tribal relations program strategic plan summary
data.landingpagecontent:
Tribal relations is the responsibility of every FS employee.  Tribal foundation is place through

  • Tribal Relations Manual and Handbook
  • Top-level Leadership orientation
  • Line Officers
  • Other personnel throughout the agency
  • Striving for outstanding public service is part of the FS organizational culture

Objectives/Goals

  • Objective 4.A – Showcase outstanding examples of collaborations with Tribes, promoting positive agency engagement to enhance tribal relations
    • Outcome – Forest Service leadership and staff, tribal leaders, tribal staff, and other partners are excited about and active in enhancing existing partnerships and creating new ones.  These partnerships will produce:
      • Resilient ecosystems
      • Enhanced cultural resilience
      • Better economies, all benefiting Indian Country and all components of the FS
  • Objective 4.B – Continuously improve how the FS creates, maintains and improves tribal relations.
    • Outcome – Forest Service employees function as a highly developed, world class team that supports the FS mission and the agency’s contributions to the well-being of tribal communities and the general American public.
  • Objective 4.C – Enhance the Forest Service’s ability to maintain an accountable process for its consultation and other interactions with Tribes.
    • The FS is able to report to Tribes and USDA our level of activity in tribal relations:
      • Allocation of resources
      • Conditions or Relationships improvement
      • FS in compliance with Executive Order 13175, Consultation and Coordination with Indian Tribal Governments
